gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Oceanographic Monitoring in Cook Inlet and Kachemak Bay, Zooplankton Data, 2012-2015, Gulf Watch Alaska Environmental Drivers Component

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Gulf Watch Alaska is the long-term ecosystem monitoring program of the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council for the marine ecosystem affected by the 1989 oil spill.

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: The webpage for the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, which was formed to oversee restoration of the injured ecosystem through the use of the $900 million civil settlement, a part which funds Research, Monitoring, and Restoration programs in Prince William Sound and the Gulf of Alaska.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: These data are part of the Gulf Watch Alaska (GWA), Environmental Drivers component of the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council, project numbers 12120114-G, 13120114-G, 14120114-G, and 16120114-G. Gulf Watch Alaska is the long-term ecosystem monitoring program of the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council for the marine ecosystem affected by the 1989 oil spill. This dataset is two comma-separated values (csv) files containing zooplankton counts by species from samples collected during Lower Cook Inlet oceanographic surveys. One data file (named' Raw') contains the raw zooplankton counts, whereas the file named 'Processed' contains the final processed counts to the lowest possible taxon. Zooplankton samples were collected during 2012-2016 as part of a long-term oceanographic monitoring project in Kachemak Bay and lower Cook Inlet . Zooplankton were collected quarterly in lower Cook Inlet and outer Kachemak Bay and monthly in Kachemak Bay with a bongo style zooplankton net: 60 cm mouth diameter/333 Î¼m mesh (Aquatic Research Instruments, Hope, ID). To calculate sample volume, a mechanical flow meter (General Oceanics) was attached to one side of the bongo frame; zooplankton were sampled from the net with no flow meter attached. At each station, 50 m vertical tows were conducted at a tow rate of approximately 0.5 m/s with an average of 14.15 m3 sampled. Preserved samples were identified and enumerated to lowest taxonomic classification possible by the Prince William Sound Science Center located in Cordova, Alaska.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The Gulf Watch Alaska program aims to provide information about the lingering oil and the recovery of species and resources injured by the spill, as well as other factors that may be affecting recovery, such as changing climate, oceanographic and ecosystem conditions. In particular, the purpose of this dataset is to determine the local plankton species and their seasonal distribution to facilitate understanding of the biological patterns associated with upper trophic levels of the nearshore marine system. The marine ecosystems of the Gulf of Alaska (GoA) and the adjoining fjords and inland passageways vary on seasonal, inter-annual, and inter-decadal time scales in response to both natural and anthropogenic influences. This variability is large at each of these time scales and quantifying it requires a long-term commitment to sustained measurements; understanding is essential for effective management and maintenance of these marine systems. The goal of the long-term monitoring program is to provide society, resource management agencies, and the science community with the knowledge and mechanistic understanding necessary to conserve, protect, and manage the marine ecosystems of the northwest Gulf of Alaska.

gmd:organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Trustee Council

gmd:maintenanceNote.gco:CharacterString: Additional zooplankton samples were collected during oceanographic cruises in Oct-Dec 2015 and Jan-Dec 2016. Analyses of these samples are underway and are expected to be complete in late 2017. This dataset will be updated when the newer data are available.

gmd:fileDescription.gco:CharacterString: The graphic file is a map of the oceanographic survey transects and the plankton stations that were sampled by this project.

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: Prior to use of these data, please contact the principal investigators and discuss your proposed use.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Oceanographic Monitoring in Cook Inlet and Kachemak Bay, CTD Data, 2012-2016, Gulf Watch Alaska Environmental Drivers Component

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: These data describe the oceanographic conditions in Kachemak Bay and lower Cook Inlet from February 2012 to December 2016 along the five identical transects that plankton were sampled. Data were collected using a Seabird SBE 19plus Seacat CTD, and processed using Seabird SBE Data Processing software. The data set is composed of HEX and CSV files, one for each study year (2012-2016). The HEX files are raw, unprocessed data files from the CTD unit. These files are provided as a ZIP archive. The CSV files are the result of applying the processing described in Process Steps to the original HEX files, aggregated across all transects for each year.

Gulf Watch Alaska: Long-term Monitoring of Marine Conditions and Injured Resources in the Gulf of Alaska Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Affected Area

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Kachemak Bay and lower Cook Inlet, Alaska

gmd:name.gco:CharacterString: Distributed Format: Data available in csv format for download in the Alaska Ocean Observing System (AOOS) Gulf of Alaska data portal.

gmd:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString: Zooplankton mechanical flow meter is flooded with fresh water before and after each sampling trip. In project year 3, the flow meter had 9 replicated tows without the mesh on the bongo net for instrument calibration.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: Five primary transects were sampled annually, three in lower Cook Inlet, and two within Kachemak Bay (refer to Oceanographic transect_plankton station map.jpg). In addition, two additional transects were sampled opportunistically within Kachemak Bay as a supplement to this project. Transect 3 is the northernmost transect in lower Cook Inlet, located between Anchor Point and Chinitna Bay. Transect 4 is a north-south line in outer Kachemak Bay from Bluff Point to near Barabara Creek. Transect 6 is the southernmost Cook Inlet line, located from Cape Douglas to near Point Adam. Transect 7 is the middle transect in lower Cook Inlet and runs along an east-west line from Flat Island to Augustine Island. Transect 9 crosses the middle of Kachemak Bay from the end of the Homer Spit to Mckeon Flat and separates inner and outer Kachemak Bay. Opportunistic sampling took place along Kachemak Bay from the mouth of the Bay to Bear Cove, as well as within the small sub bays of Kachemak Bay including Bear Cove, Peterson Bay, China Poot, Sadie Cove, Tutka Bay, and Jakolof Bay. The general oceanographic conditions for each of the primary transects is as follows: Kachemak Bay Transect 9: This transect has strong tidal exchange between inner and outer Kachemak Bay. Tidal range for this area is approximately 8.5 m and during spring snow melt, summer precipitation, and glacial meltwater inputs. There can be extensive fresh water buoyancy forcing of surface waters along this transect. Kachemak Bay Transect 4: This transect is in outer Kachemak Bay between Barabara and Bluff points. Like Transect 9, it has similar tidal exchange and buoyancy forcing during warm seasons. It is also on the edge of bathymetry derived gyre. The structure and strength of the gyre in outer Kachemak Bay may strongly influence the connectivity of water movement among water masses from the Gulf of Alaska, lower Cook Inlet, and Kachemak Bay. Lower Cook Inlet Transect 3: This transect is from Anchor Point to Red River. This transect has a strong tidal rip on the Anchor Point end, and surface water from Kachemak Bay contribute to this feature particularly during warm seasons. The northern end of the transect is strongly influenced by fresh water inputs from the Cook Inlet watershed. Of all the transects sampled, this is most likely to be vertically mixed and horizontally stratified from south to north. Lower Cook Inlet Transect 7: This transect is from Flat Island in outer Kachemak Bay to Augustine Island in Kamishak Bay. This transect is influenced by the Gulf of Alaska, the Alaska Coastal Current, and fresh water buoyancy forcing from the estuaries that contribute to the lower Cook Inlet region. It is also influenced intermittently by strong gap winds through the Alaska Range. Lower Cook Inlet Transect 6: This transect is from Point Adam in outer Kenai Peninsula to Cape Douglas on the Alaska Peninsula. This transect is influenced primarily by the Gulf of Alaska, and the Alaska Coastal Current (the Point Adam area), and fresh water buoyancy forcing from the estuaries that contribute to the lower Cook Inlet region (Cape Douglas). Gap winds from the Alaska Range also influence surface waters in this region. This transect is the deepest and longest transect in our monitoring program. Zooplankton were collected quarterly in lower Cook Inlet (as weather conditions allowed) and outer Kachemak Bay (Transects 3, 6, 7, and 4) and monthly in Kachemak Bay (Transect 9) during conccurrent Conductivity-temperature-depth (CTD) hydrographic surveys (refer to Related Resources for dataset citation for the project Oceanographic Monitoring in Cook Inlet and Kachemak Bay, CTD Data, 2012-2016, Gulf Watch Alaska Environmental Drivers Component). There are 3 stations on each of the 5 primary transects (n=15) which were sampled for zooplankton. Zooplankton were sampled with a bongo style plankton net (2 m length of 333 micron mesh with a 60 cm diameter opening (Aquatic Research Instruments)). We conducted a 50m vertical tow with a tow rate of approximately 0.5m/s. To calculate sample volume, a mechanical flow meter (General Oceans Inc. R2030) was attached to one of the two nets to estimate water volume. When the tow was complete, the mesh and cod end were washed down with salt water to concentrate plankton. The plankton sample was retrieved from the net that did not have the flow meter attached to the opening. Plankton were transferred to plastic bottles with screw-top lids and preserved with either 3 or 5% formalin solution in the field. Preserved samples were shipped to the Prince William Sound Science Center (PWSSC) for sample analysis. Zooplankton samples were subsampled with a Folsom plankton splitter (McEwan et al. 1954), identified to lowest possible taxon and stage under a stereomicroscope, and the relative abundance of each species determined. Due to the dynamic nature of this research discipline, WoRMS (World Register of Marine Species) was used for taxonomic identification: http://www.marinespecies.org/

gmd:maintenanceNote.gco:CharacterString: Additional zooplankton samples were collected during oceanographic cruises in Oct-Dec 2015 and Jan-Dec 2016. Analyses of these samples are underway and are expected to be complete in late 2017. This dataset will be updated when the newer data are available.
